Article Title: How Donald Trump’s re-election as US President may be ‘good news’ for Google
Article Text:
Trump does not back breaking up Google

Why DOJ is considering breaking up Google

Donald Trump's return to the White House may help Google which has faced scrutiny over its dominance in online search. According to a report, the 47th President-elect of the US may significantly alter the current administration's approach to antitrust enforcement, including scaling back efforts to break up Alphabet's Google.Citing experts, news agency Reuters said that Trump is expected to continue cases against Big Tech, several of which began in his first term, however, they may move forward in a new way.During President Joe Biden's term, antitrust policies against Big Tech are said to have taken a more aggressive stance with the justice department pursuing cases against Google and Apple, and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) going after Meta and Amazon.Trump has been sceptical about benefits of potential Google breakup. In an event in Chicago, Trump questioned the proposed decision of breaking up a company like Google, adding that other approaches can also be more effective in getting things done right.“If you do that, are you going to destroy the company? What you can do without breaking it up is make sure it's more fair,” he said.The DOJ is considering breaking up Google due to the company's alleged monopoly of the online search market. Recently, a federal court ruled that Google illegally monopolised the online search market by paying billions of dollars to make its search engine the default on devices like Apple's iPhones.Google has been accused of preventing competitors from entering the market, allowing Google to charge high prices for ads and degrade the quality of those ads. As a punishment, the department proposed some remedies, which includes breaking up the company, divesting Google's Android operating system and Chrome browser, and prohibiting Google from making default search agreements with third-party platforms.Google has criticised the DOJ's proposals, calling them “radical” and saying they could lead to higher prices for consumers.
Article Summary: Donald Trump's return to the White House may help Google which has faced scrutiny over its dominance in online search. The 47th President-elect of the US may significantly alter the current administration's approach to antitrust enforcement. The DOJ is considering breaking up Google due to the company's alleged monopoly of the online search market.

Article Title: Three things that Donald Trump and Elon Musk may not agree on
Article Text:
Tax credits to electric vehicle buyers and subsidies to car makers

Rule that makes it must for carmakers to buy clean air credits

Trade war with China

No corporate honcho did more to help Donald Trump win the US presidential election than Elon Musk. The Tesla and SpaceX boss went all out to support Donald Trump's election as the US President. In return, Trump has vowed to give Musk an official role — and with it, as a report in Bloomberg says, "...the power to influence policy and the federal agencies that oversee his vast empire of companies."During the campaign, Musk pitched a job for himself to cut government bureaucracy and waste. Trump embraced the idea and didn't forget to regularly mention it during his campaign. “I’m going to get Elon. And he’s great at this. He’s going to be our cost cutter,” said Trump at campaign rallies.Trump also applauded Musk’s ambitions of reaching Mars using SpaceX rockets by 2028. “We will land an American astronaut on Mars. Thank you, Elon. Thank you. Get going, Elon,” Trump said at an October rally.However, there are some policy issues that may impact the bonhomie between Donald Trump and Elon Musk. They certainly are not big enough that they can't be resolved, but yes it remains to be seen how it goes between the two on these important issues.Trump has vowed to end Biden administration policies that award tax credits to electric vehicle buyers and subsidies for carmakers that build cars and batteries in the United States. Removal of the subsidies is likely to hurt other carmakers more than Tesla, however, Tesla too would suffer.Another Republican promise that may worry Musk is the promise to eliminate the rule that requires carmakers to buy clean air credits if they fall short of pollution standards. Tesla reportedly generates a surplus of credits because it makes only electric cars. Selling the credits brought in $739 million in the third quarter, or one-third of the company’s profit.Donald Trump's presidency has created fears of the ongoing US-China trade war intensifying. Reason: Trump has promised to impose punitive tariffs on Chinese goods. Any flare up in trade war with China would also be bad for Tesla. China is one of Tesla’s largest markets, and the company operates a factory in Shanghai that exports cars around the world.
Article Summary: Tesla and SpaceX boss went all out to support Donald Trump's election as the US President. Trump has vowed to give Musk an official role — and with it, the power to influence policy and the federal agencies that oversee his vast empire of companies. Musk pitched a job for himself to cut government bureaucracy and waste.

Article Title: Google Play Store testing new 'Continue Playing' games section
Article Text:
Representative Image

Google is developing a new feature for the Play Store that will help Android users easily track and access their installed games. The "Continue Playing" section, set to appear in the Games tab, aims to streamline game access by eliminating the need to search through device launchers.The feature, discovered in version 43.4.23-31 of the Play Store app, will display installed games in a carousel format with direct launch capabilities, as reported by Android Authority. Each game listing will show either the last played timestamp for active games or the installation date for unused titles.This feature would address a common challenge on Android devices, where games often get lost among numerous installed apps without a dedicated games section in most launchers. The carousel interface prioritises recently played games, placing them at the front for quick access.While the feature appears ready for deployment, it's currently not available in the stable version of the Play Store. The timing of the public release remains unconfirmed, but the feature's apparent completion suggests it could roll out to users in an upcoming Play Store update .

Article Title: Kunal Kamra calls out Ola CEO Bhavish Aggarwal over electric scooter service issues; seeks Nitin Gadkari’s intervention
Article Text:
Kunal Kamra’s criticism: Service issues and customer discontent

Kunal Kamra’s appeal to Transport Minister Nitin Gadkari

“Minister @nitin_gadkari, please look at the plight of Indian customers. Their voices aren’t heard. They can’t get to work. They are taking bad loans to solve an issue that is primarily Ola’s responsibility. When will government agencies intervene?”

Kamra’s continued campaign for accountability

Ola’s defence and plans for improvement

Also read

In an escalating public dispute, comedian Kunal Kamra has openly criticised Ola Electric and its CEO, Bhavish Aggarwal , over service and maintenance issues concerning Ola’s electric scooters. Kamra, known for his outspoken style, recently took to X (formerly Twitter) to highlight what he describes as subpar conditions at Ola service centres, urging Transport Minister Nitin Gadkari to intervene. Citing customer complaints about inadequate repairs and a lack of qualified technicians, Kamra raised concerns about the challenges faced by Ola electric scooter owners, particularly those who rely on these scooters for daily commutes. His campaign has brought attention to wider concerns in India's rapidly growing electric vehicle (EV) sector.Kamra’s concerns began surfacing online on October 6, when he posted an image showing rows of Ola scooters awaiting repair at an Ola service centre. The comedian questioned the state of Ola’s customer service, implying that Indian consumers’ grievances were not being adequately addressed. He called on other Ola scooter owners to share their experiences, aiming to highlight issues that he believes are being ignored by the company.One post by Kamra featured a retweet of a video from an Ola customer at a Solapur service centre, where Ola electric scooters were reportedly left unattended. The video depicted a backlog of scooters in need of repairs, and Kamra commented on the absence of skilled technicians to handle the volume of work, a claim echoed by multiple Ola customers. Kamra’s tweets have generated a wave of responses from users describing issues like delayed repairs, poor customer support, and malfunctioning vehicles, reflecting broader dissatisfaction among Ola’s user base.In a notable escalation, Kamra appealed directly to Transport Minister Nitin Gadkari to address the situation, calling for government oversight. His post read:Kamra’s request for intervention highlights the potential impact on Ola’s customers, many of whom depend on their scooters for work and daily life. By appealing to Gadkari, Kamra has aimed to elevate the discussion from a customer service issue to a matter of public interest, emphasising the need for accountability from Ola Electric as it expands in India’s EV market.In response to Kamra’s criticism, Bhavish Aggarwal dismissed Kamra’s post, suggesting it was a “paid tweet.” Taking a jab at the comedian, Aggarwal sarcastically invited Kamra to “come and help us out” at Ola, claiming that Kamra would be paid a higher salary than his earnings from comedy. The comment added a personal dimension to the dispute, with Aggarwal insinuating that Kamra’s complaints were financially motivated.Kamra responded to Aggarwal’s offer by humorously accepting the "job" at Ola and listing proposed action points for the company to address. Kamra’s “acceptance” of the role highlighted his call for customer-focused improvements, including full refunds for dissatisfied customers who had purchased an Ola scooter within the last four months.Kamra has continued his online campaign, demanding transparency and tangible action from Ola Electric. He posted a video that mocked Aggarwal’s response, suggesting that the CEO’s tone was dismissive and “arrogant.” Kamra’s posts included requests for the company to address unresolved customer complaints and improve its service infrastructure, which, according to him and other users, currently struggles to meet the demands of Ola’s expanding customer base.The comedian also nicknamed Aggarwal as “Olan Musk,” drawing a comparison to Elon Musk, the high-profile CEO known for his sometimes provocative social media presence. Kamra’s comments about “Olan Musk” have further fueled public interest, sparking discussions online about the responsibility of corporate leaders in emerging industries such as EVs.In the face of growing criticism, Bhavish Aggarwal has maintained that Ola is actively working to resolve customer service issues. Ola CFO Harish Abhichandani previously stated that “99% of customer complaints” have been addressed, though Kamra and others have questioned the accuracy of this claim. According to Aggarwal, Ola is expanding its service network and hiring additional technicians to clear the backlog and improve the availability of service resources.Ola also announced plans to increase its service centres nationwide, aiming to make repairs more accessible and reduce wait times. Article Title: CEO of this German tech company announces plans to hire in India
Article Text:
SAP Labs has 15,000 employees in India

Klein on India’s role in AI

German software giant SAP is doubling down on its investment in India, with plans to significantly expand its workforce in the country, a report has said. Company CEO Christian Klein has announced that India is poised to become SAP's largest employee hub, and may surpass even its headquarters in Germany.“We will over proportionally hire here [India] versus all the other labs,” said Klein during a visit to Bengaluru with the company's executive and supervisory boards, as per news agency Reuters, which added that India will soon house the company’s biggest workforce, overtaking the headcount at company HQ.SAP Labs India currently boasts 15,000 employees, making it the company's largest engineering centre globally and its second-largest office overall. Klein emphasised India's importance to SAP, highlighting its position as one of the company's top 10 revenue generators and its fastest-growing market.He further revealed that a majority of future investments in research and development (R&D) and customer success initiatives will be directed towards India, however, Klein did not provide specific figures or timelines for hiring.The company is currently constructing a second office in Bengaluru, designed to accommodate an additional 15,000 employees.Klein also highlighted India's role in SAP's AI strategy, saying that the company's main AI team is based in India, and a growing number of development teams are led by individuals in the country.Addressing concerns about potential job losses due to the rise of generative AI (GenAI), Klein reassured employees that SAP will continue to hire as long as the business maintains its growth trajectory."As your business is growing 30% each year, you will also need more developers, not proportionally, under proportionally, but we have a growing business," he stated.
Article Summary: SAP Labs India currently boasts 15,000 employees, making it the company's largest engineering centre globally and its second-largest office overall. Company CEO Christian Klein has announced that India is poised to become SAP's largest employee hub, and may surpass even its headquarters in Germany.

Article Title: Smartphone glass maker Corning faces EU anti-competition investigation
Article Text: The European Commission has opened a formal antitrust investigation into US glass maker Corning over concerns that its exclusive supply agreements with mobile phone manufacturers may have illegally excluded competitors from the market for break-resistant screen glass.The probe will examine whether Corning, which produces the widely-used Gorilla Glass brand of protective smartphone screens, abused its dominant market position through anti-competitive practices with both phone makers and raw glass processing companies.EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager said the investigation aims to determine if Corning's practices have "deprived consumers from cheaper and more break-resistant glass" options.Regulators are specifically investigating three types of potentially anti-competitive clauses in Corning's agreements with phone manufacturers: exclusive sourcing requirements, exclusivity-based rebates, and provisions forcing manufacturers to inform Corning about competitors' offers before accepting them.The Commission is also examining Corning's contracts with glass processing companies, which allegedly included exclusive purchase obligations and clauses preventing these companies from challenging Corning's patents.If found to have violated EU competition rules , Corning could face fines of up to 10% of its global annual revenue. However, the company now has the opportunity to offer commitments to address the Commission's concerns before the investigation concludes.Corning's Alkali-aluminosilicate glass, marketed under the Gorilla Glass brand, is used to protect displays on most major smartphone brands. The material has become a standard feature in modern mobile devices due to its scratch and damage resistance properties.The Commission said it will carry out the investigation "as a matter of priority," though no deadline has been set for its completion.
Article Summary: EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager said the investigation aims to determine if Corning's practices have "deprived consumers from cheaper and more break- resistant glass" If found to have violated EU competition rules, Corning could face fines of up to 10% of its global annual revenue.

This means that even users on the latest version may not see the feature immediately. However, access is gradually expanding as more users gain the "search on web" functionality.

Article Title: Netflix offices raided in joint operation by French and Netherlands’ authorities
Article Text:
FILE PHOTO: The Netflix logo is shown on one of their Hollywood buildings in Los Angeles, California, U.S., July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File photo

French and Dutch authorities raided Netflix offices in Paris and Amsterdam on Tuesday, November 5, as part of an investigation into alleged tax fraud and concealed employment, according to French judicial sources.The searches, conducted by France's National Financial Prosecutor's Office (PNF) and corruption investigators, stem from a preliminary investigation opened in November 2022 into suspected " laundering of aggravated tax fraud " and "concealed work in an organised gang."The raids follow scrutiny of Netflix's tax declarations between 2019 and 2020, when the company's reported French revenue appeared inconsistent with its subscriber base of approximately 7 million users. According to French media outlet La Lettre, Netflix Services France paid just €981,000 ($1.06 million) in corporate taxes for 2019-2020.Netflix's declared turnover in France increased dramatically after 2020, rising from €47.1 million ($51.3 million) to €1.2 billion ($1.3 billion) in 2022, suggesting the company may have previously used tax optimization strategies through its Dutch (Netherlands) subsidiary.The simultaneous searches at Netflix's European headquarters in Amsterdam were conducted through cooperation between French and Dutch authorities that has been ongoing for several months, officials said.This is not Netflix's first tax-related issue in Europe. In 2022, the streaming giant paid €55.8 million ($59.1 million) to settle a tax dispute with Italian authorities.Netflix, which opened its Paris office in 2020 and employs around 40 staff there, has not responded to requests for comment on the raids. The company produces several original series in France, including the hit show "Emily in Paris."A preliminary investigation in France does not necessarily lead to criminal charges or a trial.
Article Summary: French and Dutch authorities raided Netflix offices in Paris and Amsterdam on Tuesday, November 5. Raids follow scrutiny of Netflix's tax declarations between 2019 and 2020. Netflix Services France paid just €981,000 ($1.06 million) in corporate taxes for 2019-2020.

Article Title: Donald Trump vs Kamala Harris: What Trump or Harris win in US elections 2024 may mean for H-1B visa aspirants

US Election Results 2024: The day of reckoning has come. The counting is live in a historic presidential contest between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris. One of the biggest things that may affect Indians is the stance of the duo on H-1B visa. So it is likely that she would likely implement reforms aimed at expanding opportunities for immigrants and international students. However, what she remains mum on are the matter of country-specific caps on green cards.During her 2019 campaign, Harris endorsed lifting these caps, acknowledging that over 95% of green card applicants are from India, China, the Philippines, and Vietnam. There has been no change in this policy during Joe Biden's tenure.Donald Trump's first term saw attempts to restrict the H-1B visa programme by narrowing eligibility criteria and increasing scrutiny of applications. His re-election means more regulations, such as higher wage requirements for H-1B holders to ensure that these positions do not displace American workers. At the same time, in a surprising shift from his usual hardline stance on immigration, Trump expressed his desire to grant automatic green cards to foreign students who graduate from US colleges. During an interview on the "All-In" podcast, in July, Trump said, "What I want to do and what I will do is, you graduate from a college, I think you should get a green card automatically as part of your diploma, a green card to be able to stay in this country." He extended this proposal to include graduates from two-year junior colleges and doctoral programs.Trump's changed stance is a boost for Indian students studying in US colleges. Trump further highlighted the loss of talent due to current visa policies, saying, "I know of stories where people graduated from a top college, or from a college, and they desperately want to stay here... and they can't. They go back to India, they go back to China. They do the same basic company in those places and they become multibillionaires employing thousands and thousands of people."
Article Summary: The election of Donald Trump or Kamala Harris to US President may impact India and Indians. This includes areas like trade, immigration and more. One of the biggest things that may affect Indians is the stance of the duo on H-1B visa. Trump's changed stance is a boost for Indian students studying in US colleges.

Article Title: Google Workspace chief Aparna Pappu steps down, Jerry Dischler named successor
Article Text:
What Google said

Jerry Dischler to be Workspace’s new head



Aparna Pappu, vice president and general manager - Google Workspace is stepping down from her current role. She has headed the unit since July 2022, succeeding Javier Soltero, former head of Workspace and longtime Microsoft veteran. According to Business Insider, Pappu informed the employees in a memo last week. “I'm ready for the next opportunity at Google and stepping down from my current role as GM of Workspace,” she said.Pappu said that she would remain in an advisory position for Workspace before transitioning to a new role within Google. "That's really the best feeling of all — when your team has 'got this,''" she wrote. "And we've especially got this AI thing — we know what we need to do and we're razor focused on execution. "With all that in mind, I knew it was time for something new for me."Confirming the change, a Google spokesperson said “After more than six years working on Workspace, Aparna Pappu is ready for her next challenge at Google and will be moving to a new role.”Aparna Pappu will be replaced by Jerry Dischler, president of cloud applications. She said her senior reports, including Anurag Agarwal, Google Workspace's vice president of engineering, and Yulie Kwon Kim, vice president of product, would now report to Dischler.He worked on Google’s ads for 15 years and earlier this year, moved to a new role as Google's president of cloud applications. Dischler reports to Google Cloud CEO Thomas Kurian. His role heavily centers on integrating AI into customers' businesses.
Article Summary: Aparna Pappu, vice president and general manager - Google Workspace is stepping down from her current role. She has headed the unit since July 2022, succeeding Javier Soltero, former head of Workspace and longtime Microsoft veteran. She will be replaced by Jerry Dischler, president of cloud applications.

Article Title: Lower tax rates, SpaceX contracts and more: How Elon Musk may become the biggest winner of Donald Trump's second term as US President
Article Text:
Donald Trump's tax cuts may favor Musk

Trump presidency may ease regulatory pressure on Musk’s empire

Tesla CEO Elon Musk could gain significant advantages if former President Donald Trump returns to the White House, reports NBC News. Musk, who is openly supporting Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, the report says, could also play an influential role in a second Trump administration.Brian Hughes, a Trump campaign senior adviser, told NBC News that Trump wants Musk to lead a “commission” that will “ensure our government works more efficiently and uses America’s taxpayer dollars effectively.” “As President Trump has said, Elon Musk is a genius, an innovator, and has literally made history by building creative, modern, and efficient systems,” he added.Trump has been open about his intent to maintain low tax rates for corporations and wealthy individuals like Musk. During his previous tenure, he lowered the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21% in 2017. In April, he told wealthy donors in Palm Beach, Florida, that he hopes to extend the tax cuts from his prior administration.While tax burdens for individual corporations and high earners vary depending on deductions and tax strategies, Trump’s plan would keep a reduced rate for the highest-income earners, with his 2017 law having lowered the top income tax rate from 39.6% to 37%. According to a September report by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, extending Trump’s tax cuts for another 10 years would direct 41% of the benefits toward high-income households through rate cuts, special deductions, and inheritance tax reductions. (The Trump campaign has not yet responded to the report.)With Trump being elected as US president for the second term, Elon Musk’s SpaceX is projected to keep securing billions annually in government contracts, including deals with the Defense Department and NASA. SpaceX remains NASA's sole option for transporting astronauts to and from the International Space Station, as Boeing's Starliner spacecraft faces ongoing issues.Elon Musk has engaged in at least 19 regulatory and legal disputes with the Biden administration and federal agencies over recent years, NBC News reports. These 19 cases involve 12 different government entities and cover a range of issues—from environmental concerns at a SpaceX launch site near a Texas wildlife refuge to alleged racial harassment at a California Tesla factory and Tesla’s marketing of its driver-assistance software as “full self-driving” despite needing human oversight.Beyond his business empire, Musk’s America PAC is also facing legal challenges, including one with Philadelphia District Attorney Larry Krasner over $1 million daily prize giveaways by the PAC. On Monday, a judge refused to block the cash prizes.Angela Aneiros, a law professor at Gonzaga University and co-director of its Center for Law, Ethics & Commerce said “A second Trump term could reshape the regulatory landscape in ways that benefit Musk’s companies,”. If Trump returns, she added, federal agencies may shift away from investigating regulatory compliance and prioritize issues like immigration enforcement instead.
Article Summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk could gain significant advantages if former President Donald Trump returns to the White House. Trump has been open about his intent to maintain low tax rates for corporations and wealthy individuals like Musk. Musk has engaged in at least 19 regulatory and legal disputes with the Biden administration and federal agencies.

Article Title: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy explains why he wants fewer managers: ‘… because it's not a political..’
Article Text:
‘I hate bureaucracy’: Amazon CEO

Amazon introduces ‘Bureacracy Mailbox’

Amazon CEO Andy Jassy recently shared the reasons behind the company's decision to reduce its number of managers. At an internal all-hands meeting, Jassy said that the aim is to streamline decision making and reduce management layers that are killing Amazon's unique culture, as reported by Business Insider.“The reality is that the S team and I hate bureaucracy,” Jassy said, referring to the senior leadership. “One of the reasons I'm still at this company is because it's not a political or bureaucratic place.”“We have a chance to build the most remarkable company in the history of business. But I also would say that I'm not sure that there's been a more important time in the history of this company with the way technology is changing, especially with AI, for us to be well set up to innovate together and to collaborate together and to be connected to one another and to understand the culture, and that's what we're optimizing for.”“The goal again is to allow us to have higher ownership and to move more quickly,” Jassy said.He also explained that these changes are essential for Amazon in light of the fast-evolving technology landscape and increasing competitive pressure. In the tech industry, only a handful of companies last 50 or 100 years because "the world changes, technology changes, competitors change, companies change," he noted.In September, Amazon revealed its plans to raise the ratio of individual contributors to managers by 15% by the end of the first quarter of 2025. An internal document indicated that this shift may lead to role eliminations as the company identifies overlapping positions. The e-commerce giant also announced a new "Bureacracy Mailbox" last month allowing employees to voice concerns about unnecessary or excessive processes and suggest areas for improvement.Jassy told employees that he has received over 500 email through the bureaucracy inbox and the company has taken action on more than 150 of these suggestions.
Article Summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy recently shared the reasons behind the company's decision to reduce its number of managers. At an internal all-hands meeting, Jassy said that the aim is to streamline decision making and reduce management layers. He also explained that these changes are essential for Amazon in light of the fast- evolving technology landscape and increasing competitive pressure.

Article Title: Google CEO Sundar Pichai to employees in internal memo: Whoever wins US elections, "... let's remember the role ..."
Article Text:
Here’s the full memo sent by Sundar Pichai

Hi Googlers,

Tomorrow is election day here and many in the U.S. will be heading to the polls to vote for everything from school board to judges to the Congress and President.

Teams across Google and YouTube have been working hard to make sure our platforms provide voters with high-quality and reliable information, just as we’ve done for so many other elections around the world — in fact, dozens of countries have held major, hotly contested elections this year, from France to India to the UK to Mexico and many more, with well over a billion people casting votes in 2024.

We should be proud of our work, and also of our teams’ efforts to keep campaigns secure, to deliver accurate information on where and how to vote, and to provide digital advertising solutions to campaigns. Thanks to everyone working around the clock on these efforts throughout the campaign season and as votes are tallied.

As with other elections, the outcome will be a major topic of conversation in living rooms and other places around the world. And of course, the outcome will have important consequences.

Whomever the voters entrust, let’s remember the role we play at work, through the products we build and as a business: to be a trusted source of information to people of every background and belief. We will and must maintain that. In that spirit, it’s important that everyone continue to follow our Community Guidelines and Personal Political Activity Policy.

Beyond election day, our work to organize the world’s information and make it universally accessible and useful will continue. Al has given us a profound opportunity to make progress on that mission, build great products and partnerships, drive innovation, and make significant contributions to national and local economies. Our company is at its best when we’re focused on that.

Thanks, Sundar

Google has refuted these claims.First reported by The Washing Post, the CEO has sent an internal memo to its employee. In the memo obtained by The Verge, Pichai said that “We should be proud of our work, and also of our teams’ efforts to keep campaigns secure, to deliver accurate information on where and how to vote, and to provide digital advertising solutions to campaigns.” Pichai also stated that “Al has given us a profound opportunity to make progres” to make information universally accessible.

Article Title: Google wins case over gift card scam dating back to 2015
Article Text:
What is Google Play gift card scam and why the company was sued

Google has won a lawsuit over Google Play gift card scams with a judge ruling that the tech company is not liable for losses incurred by such fraud. A lawsuit claimed that the search giant illegally profited from gift card scams by refusing to refund victims.Citing a decision by US District Judge Beth Labson Freeman, news agency Reuters reported that the plaintiff, Judy May, has failed to demonstrate that Google caused her losses or knowingly received stolen funds. May lost $1,000 in a scam where she was tricked into buying Google Play gift cards.The judge also determined that Google was not liable for retaining its standard commissions –15% to 30% – on purchases made with the gift cards, as this practice was unrelated to the initial fraud.While Freeman dismissed the lawsuit, she granted May the option to refile her case. However, a claim for triple damages was permanently dismissed, the report said.A class action lawsuit against Google was filed earlier this year, alleging that the tech giant illegally profited from gift card scams by refusing to refund victims.The lawsuit stemmed from a $1,000 loss suffered by Indiana resident Judy May, who fell victim to a scammer posing as a relative. The scammer convinced May to purchase Google Play gift cards under the pretence of securing federal grant money. May provided the gift card codes to the scammer, who then used them to make purchases.A class action complaint claimed that “over nearly a decade, Google has knowingly kept millions of dollars in stolen money from victims of gift card scams who purchased Google Play gift cards.”The lawsuit argued that Google should have warned consumers about scams on gift card packaging andthat anyone demanding payment with the cards was a scammer. She also accused the company of profiting from the fraudulent activity by keeping commissions on purchases made with stolen gift cards.
Article Summary: Judy May lost $1,000 in a scam where she was tricked into buying Google Play gift cards. A lawsuit claimed that the search giant illegally profited from gift card scams by refusing to refund victims. Judge ruled that May has failed to demonstrate that Google caused her losses or knowingly received stolen funds.

Article Title: How Lina Khan, for whom Elon Musk wrote she "will be fired soon" became a hot topic of the US election
Article Text:
Why many companies are unhappy with Lina Khan

In the lead-up to the election, Lina Khan , chair of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), has faced criticism from both Democrats and Republicans. Prominent Democratic donors, including billionaires Reid Hoffman, Barry Diller, and Mark Cuban, have called for her removal from the agency. More recently, a report from the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee accused her of pursuing a far-left agenda and weaponizing the FTC. Elon Musk, the biggest supporter of Donald Trump 's in Silicon Valley, wrote on Twitter that Khan "will be fired soon."A report in the New York Times talks about how Khan, nominated in 2021 by President Joe Biden , became one of the hottest topics of the US Elections 2024. At 35, she is the youngest-ever chairman of FTC.She reportedly has become a focal point of bipartisan attention. This level of scrutiny is said to be unusual for a leader of the FTC, which typically operates under the radar while regulating companies that undermine competition. The NYT report said that the intense focus on Khan reflects the high stakes of the Biden administration's efforts to curb the power of America's largest corporations, a programme that could be reversed by the next president.Dwelling further the report adds that FTC and Justice Department scrutiny has led to the collapse of several major corporate deals, with lawsuits potentially breaking up big brands like Google, Amazon, and Ticketmaster's parent company. Khan has advocated for regulating artificial intelligence, ordered companies to simplify online subscription cancellations, and banned noncompete agreements that prevent workers from joining rival employers.The business community and its Washington allies have fiercely opposed Khan's actions. Representative James Comer, R-Ky., reportedly criticized her leadership, claiming she would stop at nothing to achieve the radical left's goals. Amazon and Meta have called for her recusal from investigations and lawsuits due to her previous criticisms. Lobbying groups have complained that her actions are chilling the economy.In a September interview with The New York Times, Khan acknowledged the criticism but dismissed much of it, emphasizing the importance of considering diverse voices and keeping the entire country in mind. She expressed uncertainty about her future in a "60 Minutes" interview, stating it would be an honor to continue in her role.Many observers expect Trump to replace Khan if he wins the election, as presidents typically appoint leaders from their own party to agencies like the FTC. Former FTC chair Bill Kovacic believes Khan's tenure would be short-lived under a Trump administration. Khan's fate under Vice President Kamala Harris is less certain, as her term expired in September. The next president could replace her by appointing a new chair or designating one of the other commissioners.Khan, who gained prominence as a scholar advocating for stricter antitrust laws against companies like Amazon, became the youngest leader of the FTC in its history. She revived an FTC lawsuit to break up Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, and sued Amazon for allegedly monopolizing online retail. The FTC also unsuccessfully attempted to block Microsoft's acquisition of Activision Blizzard and is fighting to block Kroger's $24.6 billion acquisition of Albertsons.
Article Summary: Lina Khan, 35, is the youngest-ever chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. She has faced criticism from both Democrats and Republicans. Elon Musk, the biggest supporter of Donald Trump's in Silicon Valley, wrote on Twitter that Khan "will be fired soon"

Article Title: US election 2024 -- Kamala Harris vs Donald Trump: On whose side are America's biggest tech CEOs and leaders
Article Text:
The 2024 US election sees Silicon Valley divided, with prominent figures backing either Kamala Harris or Donald Trump. Harris enjoys support from figures like Mark Cuban and Sheryl Sandberg, while Elon Musk and Peter Thiel rally behind Trump. Notably, tech giants like Microsoft and Google remain silent on their endorsements.

Kamala Harris supporters in Silicon Valley

Shark Tank judge Mark Cuban

Read more:

Co-founder Sun Microsystems and investor Vinod Khosla

Facebook's former COO Sheryl Sandberg

Netflix executive chairman Reed Hastings

LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman

Supporters of Donald Trump in Silicon Valley

PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel

Venture capitalists Marc Andreesen and Ben Horowitz

Former head of Sequoia Capital Douglas Leone

Tech CEOs who have not openly announced their support

The United States is witnessing one of the most tightly contested elections in recent history. Analysts suggest a near photo finish between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump. Some have even hinted that national polls may see a near tie, with slight variations between states. The US election 2024 is widely regarded as one of the most divisive in American history. Both Harris and Trump have repeatedly warned against potentially catastrophic consequences if the other is elected. Voters too are said to hold vastly different views on key issues such as the economy, immigration, and abortion rights. As the elections reach the finishing line, here's a look at the biggest supporters of Kamala Harris and Donald Trump in Silicon Valley, as well as those who didn't openly share their allegiance with either of them.Tech entrepreneur Mark Cuban, widely known for his role as a judge on the reality show Shark Tank, has publicly endorsed Kamala Harris, citing her non-ideological stance. Cuban, who supported Trump in 2015, believes a second Trump administration would be detrimental to small businesses.Another staunch supporter of Kamala Harris is Vinod Khosla. The prominent Silicon Valley investor with stakes in startups like DoorDash, Stripe, and Instacart has openly declared his support for Harris.Facebook's former COO Sheryl Sandberg endorsed Harris shortly after President Joe Biden withdrew from the race. Sandberg praised Harris as an accomplished leader and a strong advocate for abortion rights, expressing her excitement to support her.Reed Hastings, Netflix executive chairman, has contributed over $7 million to Harris' presidential campaign through a super political action committee (PAC).LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman joined 88 business leaders in signing an open letter supporting Harris for the presidency.Though OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has not publicly endorsed any candidate, but the Harris Victory Fund reportedly received a donation from him, according to Fortune.On the other hand, tech mogul and the world's richest man Elon Musk has emerged as a significant supporter of Donald Trump in this election. The Tesla and SpaceX CEO, who refrained from endorsing anyone in 2020, is now actively campaigning for Trump both on the ground and on X, the platform he owns. Musk has expressed willingness to lead a government department if Trump wins and has voiced concerns about potential imprisonment if Harris becomes president.Musk has used his wealth to influence the election, including a $1 million daily giveaway to a random person in a swing state, which the US Department of Justice argued was illegal. However, a district court in Pennsylvania declined to block the giveaway.PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel, a major investor in Facebook, has stated he will vote for Trump but will not contribute financially to his campaign. Thiel remains strongly pro-Trump and pro-JD, supporting them in other ways.Marc Andreesen and Ben Horowitz, leaders of one of Silicon Valley's largest venture capital firms, are backing Trump, criticizing the Biden administration for over-regulation and taxation, as reported by TechCrunch.Former head of Sequoia Capital Douglas Leone is also supporting Trump, expressing concerns about the country's direction, immigration system, deficit, and foreign policy.Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, Google CEO Sundar Pichai, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, Facebook parent Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Apple CEO Tim Cook have not openly endorsed any candidate as the next US President.
Article Summary: The 2024 US election sees Silicon Valley divided, with prominent figures backing either Kamala Harris or Donald Trump. Harris enjoys support from figures like Mark Cuban and Sheryl Sandberg, while Elon Musk and Peter Thiel rally behind Trump. Notably, tech giants like Microsoft and Google remain silent on their endorsements.

Article Title: No Diwali cheer in India's smartwatch market; Apple and Samsung the only exceptions
Article Text:
A Sectoral Slowdown

Apple and Samsung seeing growth

India's wearable market, particularly mass-segment smartwatches, has faced a significant downturn over the past year, despite the festive season's traditional boost. This trend is reflected in the financial performance of two of the major players like Boat and Boult. According to a report in Economic Times, "The festive season failed to arrest a downturn in India’s wearables market, particularly mass-segment smartwatches, over the last 12-15 months even as its impact has become visible in the financials of device makers."Warburg Pincus-backed Boat, while reducing its losses by 48%, saw a decline in its FY24 revenue. Conversely, Boult witnessed a halving of its profits due to increased spending on growth initiatives.The broader wearables segment, encompassing wireless audio devices and smartwatches, experienced a 10% year-on-year decline in shipments during the April-June quarter. This downturn, attributed to cautious inventory management and fewer new product launches, has disproportionately affected the smartwatch category. The homegrown wearable and audio products firm recorded a 5% decline in revenue for the fiscal year ended March 2024 to Rs 3,122 crore.Anshika Jain, senior research analyst at data analytics firm Counterpoint, told Economic Times, “During this festive period, India’s smartwatch sales have remained sluggish, extending the downward trend from the previous quarter.” “We anticipate a double-digit year-over-year decline in sales, attributed to limited discounts and changing consumer behaviour,” she added.A 30% decline is anticipated in smartwatch shipments in the September quarter, she said. “Consumers are not replacing smartwatches as quickly as the industry had anticipated,” Jain said, adding that this led to inventory pile-up of these products. Industry analysts predict a continued decline in smartwatch shipments, particularly in the mass-market segment.The audio products category appears to be better. Here the mass market managed to sustain growth. The true wireless(TWS) audio segment, dominated by wireless earphones and headsets, remains a bright spot. Companies are focusing on introducing advanced features like active noise cancellation at more affordable price points to drive growth. Offline expansion and the emergence of quick commerce channels are playing a crucial role in shaping the wearable market. Companies like Boult are leveraging these channels to boost sales and reach a wider audience.While the mass market is seeing growth pains, the premium segment, driven by new releases from Samsung and Apple, is expected to witness substantial growth. "The premium segment is projected to experience significant growth, fuelled by new releases from Samsung and Apple, along with discounts on older models,” Jain said.
Article Summary: Boat, while reducing its losses by 48%, saw a decline in its FY24 revenue. Boult witnessed a halving of its profits due to increased spending on growth initiatives. The broader wearables segment experienced a 10% year-on-year decline in shipments during the April-June quarter.

Article Title: Sony sues CBS; blames job cuts at Paramount Global for ‘dismal performance
Article Text: Sony Pictures Television has filed a lawsuit against CBS Studios, alleging the network has failed to maximise revenues and engaged in self-dealing in its distribution of popular game shows "Jeopardy!" and "Wheel of Fortune."The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court, claims CBS has made over $1 billion in profit from a 35-year distribution agreement while undervaluing the shows' licensing fees and advertising potential. Sony argues that CBS's recent corporate restructuring and layoffs have severely impacted its ability to properly distribute the programs.According to the complaint, CBS entered unauthorised international distribution deals in Australia and New Zealand, pocketing $3.6 million in fees without proper compensation to Sony. The studio also alleges CBS has been licensing the shows domestically below market value and bundling them with less popular CBS-owned programs like "The Hot Bench" and "The Drew Barrymore Show."Sony claims that when it became directly involved in negotiations with ABC stations, licensing fees grew by 17%, compared to CBS' projected flat to 2% growth. The lawsuit cites recent layoffs at CBS parent Paramount Global , which eliminated 2,800 positions, as contributing to "dismal performance" in fulfilling distribution obligations.CBS strongly denied the allegations in a statement, saying it has been an "accomplished distribution partner and thoughtful steward" for both shows over 40 years. The network argues it holds perpetual distribution rights and claims Sony "simply doesn't like the deal the parties agreed to decades ago."
Article Summary: Sony Pictures Television has filed a lawsuit against CBS Studios. The studio claims the network has failed to maximise revenues and engaged in self-dealing in its distribution of popular game shows "Jeopardy!" and "Wheel of Fortune" The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court, claims CBS has made over $1 billion in profit from a 35-year distribution agreement.

Article Title: China's Alibaba cuts more jobs as part of broader restructuring effort
Article Text:
Not the First Job Cuts

Financial Pressures

Competition Heats Up

Chinese giant Alibaba Group has laid off a significant number of employees at Yuanjing, its division dedicated to the Metaverse. This move signals a scaling back of the company's ambitions in the virtual world, according to sources cited by the South China Morning Post.The layoffs are reported to be part of a broader restructuring effort focused on optimizing efficiency within Alibaba. Established in 2021, Yuanjing aimed to capitalize on the Metaverse's potential, joining other Chinese tech giants like Tencent, ByteDance, Kuaishou, and Li Auto in the race to explore this virtual space.Incidentally, Alibaba's scaling back of its metaverse ambitions isn't an isolated event. It reflects a trend within the global tech industry where companies are reevaluating their investments in the nascent metaverse space.The recent layoffs, first reported by Chinese media on November 1, affect operations in Shanghai and Hangzhou. This isn't Alibaba's first workforce reduction – in February 2023, the company let go of over 4,000 employees. The year before, a larger workforce reduction of approximately 19,000 employees took place as Alibaba adapted to a challenging global economic climate and prioritized cost-efficiency.Alibaba's recent financial performance has also played a role in the metaverse retreat. The company missed market expectations for its first-quarter revenue in August 2024. This shortfall reflects declining domestic e-commerce sales as Chinese consumers tighten their spending due to a faltering economy.Alibaba also faces intense competition from rivals like JD.com and discount-oriented retail platforms such as Pinduoduo (PDD Holdings) and Douyin (owned by ByteDance). The company's revenue of 243.24 billion yuan ($33.98 billion) for the quarter ending June 30th, 2024 fell short of analysts' expectations, highlighting the competitive landscape of the Chinese tech industry.
Article Summary: Alibaba Group has laid off a significant number of employees at Yuanjing, its division dedicated to the Metaverse. The layoffs are reported to be part of a broader restructuring effort focused on optimizing efficiency within Alibaba. This isn't Alibaba's first workforce reduction – in February 2023, the company let go of over 4,000 employees.
